fact_cards.title: Coastal Durability: Granite
fact_cards.scientific_fact: Granite is an igneous rock with extreme density, making it virtually impervious to salt spray corrosion.
fact_cards.geo_template: For homes in **{city}**, we often recommend granite over poured concrete because it withstands the coastal salt air and freeze-thaw cycles of Zone 6b.

fact_cards.title: Erosion Control
fact_cards.scientific_fact: Gravity retaining walls utilize their own weight and proper drainage aggregate to hold back soil pressure and prevent runoff.
fact_cards.geo_template: In hilly areas like **{city}**, stabilizing slopes is critical to protecting your foundation. Proper drainage behind the wall prevents the 'heaving' common in New England winters.

fact_cards.title: Acidic Soil Blooms
fact_cards.scientific_fact: Hydrangea macrophylla blooms shift blue in acidic soils (pH < 5.5) and pink in alkaline soils.
fact_cards.geo_template: The naturally acidic soil of **Essex County** creates the deep blue hydrangea blooms iconic to the North Shore. We select cultivars proven to survive our winters.

fact_cards.title: Water Management
fact_cards.scientific_fact: Hydrostatic pressure from standing water is the leading cause of basement leaks and hardscape failure.
fact_cards.geo_template: Managing the spring thaw is a priority for properties in **{city}**. We install dry wells and french drains to redirect water away from your home's foundation.

fact_cards.title: Flexible Pavement Systems
fact_cards.scientific_fact: Interlocking pavers allow for ground movement without cracking, unlike rigid concrete slabs.
fact_cards.geo_template: Because the ground in **{city}** freezes and expands, pavers are a smart investment. They 'flex' with the frost heave rather than cracking like asphalt or concrete.
